awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Lee Waves and Turbulence Forced by the Kuroshio
awd_abstract_narration:
Roughly 1 TW is input into the ocean circulation by wind-work. How this balanced energy is dissipated to maintain steady state remains uncertain but is important for correctly modeling balanced energy pathways in ocean general circulation models. Loss to lee-wave generation followed by turbulence production has been hypothesized to account for 20-75 percent. The research will clarify lee-wave generation and the waves' role in dissipating vs. redistributing balanced energy. Results from this project will be presented at conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals to make them available to the wider scientific community. Data will be archived at public sites at University of Washington (UW) Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) and Northwest Research Associates. An improved model parameterization for the dissipation and redistribution of balanced flows and induced mixing by lee-wave generation is an expected outcome. The project will support a postdoctoral researcher in data analysis and internal-wave physics. Seattle K-12 classroom visits and active engagement with UW and local science centers is planned. The project will also contribute to the summer program for UW undergraduate students and the annual Pacific Science Center Polar Science Weekend.

Lee-wave generation (0.2-0.75 TW) and bottom drag (~0.25 TW) are two hypothesized sinks. The passage of the Kuroshio through Tokara Strait affords an accessible case to evaluate lee-wave generation and dissipation that impact a major western boundary current. It has been assumed that lee-wave generation is lost to turbulence. However, measurements in Antarctic Circumpolar Current jets find that turbulent dissipation rates fall short of predictions by as much as an order of magnitude. Measurements will be made to study internal lee-wave generation and evolution, hydraulic jumps, turbulence and water-mass transformation where the Kuroshio crosses a seamount chain in Tokara Strait. Line-arrays of chi-augmented EMAPEX profiling floats will be deployed at across-stream locations upstream of the seamount chain to be swept across by the Kuroshio, obtaining along-stream/depth sections from the surface to the bottom (< 600 m depth), and from up- to downstream of the shoal topography with a focus on the flow structure and turbulence in the lee.  These measurements will address whether lee-wave generation and bottom drag represent major sinks for balanced flows. These measurements will offer a more complete assessment of lee-wave generation and the fate of lee waves than has hitherto been performed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Processes responsible for the energy cascade in the ocean from submeso-scale, small-scale, fine-scale, to microscale for turbulence mixing and dissipation remain not fully understood. These oceanic processes span horizontal lengthscales from O(100 km) to O(mm) and vertical scales from O(100s m) to O(mm). They have distinct dynamics, carry different energy exchange rates and energy cascade rates, and exist in different energetic regimes, e.g., linear, weakly nonlinear, and strongly nonlinear regimes. Numerical models and laboratory experiments are not capable of  simulating oceanic processes across 9 orders of horizontal scales. Observational effort to measure these processes is even more challenging because of the inherent instrumental and sampling limitations in the oceanic field experiment. 

The overarching scientific goals of this project are to measure finescale and microscale response to interaction of the Kuroshio with a seamount to better understand its role in energizing finescale internal wave and vortex wake motions, dissipating a western boundary current and mixing the water column.  This involves disentangling internal lee-wave generation and evolution, hydraulic jumps, wake vortices, bottom boundary turbulence, anisotropic turbulence, sub-mesoscale instability, and turbulent dissipation in a highly nonlinear regime.

An array of 10 EM-APEX floats, combined with ADCP-CTD moorings and shipboard ADCP, underway-CTD, and microstructure surveys were used to make measurements from submesoscale to microscale to try to capture the dominant dynamic processes responsible for the energy cascade as the Kuroshio interacts with a seamount in Tokara Strait off Japan. Five field experiments were car 

Elevated finescale variance and enhanced turbulence intensity were observed behind the wake of seamount. Vertical shear of horizontal velocities and vertical strain are at least an order of magnitude above the canonical Garrett-Munk internal-wave levels in the open ocean.  Vertical wavenumber spectra of vertical shear roll off at 0.01 cpm, indicating significant shear at large vertical scales comparable to the local water depth of 600m and implying that the flow regime is highly nonlinear.  Observed processes cannot be interpreted as linear internal waves (e.g., the Garrett-and-Munk model spectrum) or quasi-geostrophic motions. Vertical wavenumber spectra of vertical divergence are 1-2 orders of magnitude higher than the GM model in the wake of the seamount.  Spectral levels of vertical divergence increase with TKE dissipation rate ε, suggesting that vertical divergence is not saturated as vertical shear and strain.

Turbulence is strongly enhanced in two layers.  Between 150-300 m depth (summit depth), turbulence kinetic energy dissipation rates ε  is about 10–6 W/kg, and turbulent thermal diffusivities K ~ 10–2 m2/s and the turbulence outer scale Ozmidov scale of ~10 m.  This layer extends at least 20 km downstream of the seamount.  Potential processes responsible for the enhanced turbulence downstream of the seamount include anisotropic stratified turbulence generated at the seamount, internal lee waves encountering a critical layer further downstream from the seamount at the base of the Kuroshio, and persistent submesoscale symmetric instability downstream of the seamount. Comparable turbulence also occurs in the deeper layer between 350-450 m depth, but is only found 10 km downstream of the seamount. Observed turbulence kinetic energy dissipation rates are reasonably predicted using finescale internal wave shear/strain parameterization, reduced-shear-variance scaling, and a large-eddy parameterization.

Turbulence kinetic energy dissipation rate is estimated by applying Thorpe-scale and reduced-shear turbulence parameterizations on measurements taken from the long-term ADCP/CTD mooring. Depth averaged turbulence kinetic energy rates estimated from these two independent methods are significantly correlated and have a mean value of O(10–6 W/kg), consistent with that measured directly from EM-APEX floats.  Frequency spectra of depth averaged turbulence kinetic energy rates show a clear spectral peak at semidiurnal frequency. Depth averaged estimates of turbulence kinetic energy dissipation rates are correlated with the Kuroshio current speeds as ε ~ U3.
